title: Neil McLennan
text:
Neil McLennan (September 2, 1777, 1778, or 1787 – 1867) was an early <a href="Scottish-American">Scottish-American</a> settler of Texas. <a href="McLennan%20County%2C%20Texas">McLennan County, Texas</a>, was named for him.
McLennan was born on the <a href="Isle%20of%20Skye">Isle of Skye</a> in Scotland. In 1801, he and a large group of family and friends immigrated to <a href="Richmond%20County%2C%20North%20Carolina">Richmond County, North Carolina</a>, later moving further south to Florida. The McLennans were <a href="Scottish%20Gaelic">Gaelic</a> speakers and <a href="Presbyterian">Presbyterian</a>s. Around 1820, they were invited by <a href="Yuchi">Yuchi</a> Chief <a href="Sam%20Story">Sam Story</a> to become the first <a href="European%20colonization%20of%20the%20Americas">white settlers</a> in <a href="Walton%20County%2C%20Florida">Walton County, Florida</a>. In December, 1834, Neil and his brothers Laughlin and John, along with some of their families and friends, immigrated to Texas, sailing a self-built three-masted <a href="schooner">schooner</a> from <a href="Pensacola%2C%20Florida">Pensacola, Florida</a>, to the mouth of the <a href="Brazos%20River">Brazos River</a>, where they arrived in March, 1835.
After a short stay at present-day <a href="Columbus%2C%20Texas">Columbus, Texas</a>, Neil obtained a grant of a <a href="League%20%28unit%29%23Spain">league</a> of land at McLennan's Bluff (a mile west of present-day <a href="Rosebud%2C%20Texas">Rosebud</a>, <a href="Falls%20County%2C%20Texas">Falls County</a>) in <a href="Robertson%27s%20Colony">Robertson's Colony</a> in July, 1835, where he and his group settled. Laughlin McLennan and his wife and mother were killed in an <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Indian</a> raid the following winter, and John was likewise killed in 1838, after which the McLennan group moved to the Robertson Colony's headquarters of Nashville-on-the-Brazos in present-day <a href="Milam%20County%2C%20Texas">Milam County</a>.
In 1845, Neil McLennan moved his family to a site on the <a href="Bosque%20River">Bosque River</a> near present-day <a href="Waco%2C%20Texas">Waco</a>, and he died at his home there in 1867, renowned as "the patriarch of the Bosque."
